image.altText: A crowd of people, some wearing hi-vis vests, gather beside several trucks loaded with covered goods as they emerge from a wall.

items.synopsis: Israel allows trucks carrying food, water and medicine through the southern crossing from Egypt into Gaza, ahead of a potential invasion, the Associated Press reports.Â Follow live.

title.children: Rafah crossing opens to allow trucks carrying humanitarian aid into Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Twenty truck loads of aid has arrived in Gaza city after days of diplomatic wrangling over conditions for delivering the relief goods. Ahmad Nassar, a Red Crescent Manager in Gaza spoke to Reuters after the medication and food was brought to a UN facility. "Today we received around 20 trucks of aid, of course this number is not in any way sufficient to cover the humanitarian need in Gaza, since there is a humanitarian crisis in the strip, the deteriorating conditions in the strip requires a lot more than aid, initially what is needed, is the stop of the aggression on Gaza, and then the rebuilding of Gaza and elevating the humanitarian situation of the population," he says. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Humanitarian aid trucks arrive in Gaza city

children.content: Twenty truck loads of aid has arrived in Gaza city after days of diplomatic wrangling over conditions for delivering the relief goods.
(Reuters)

"Today we received around 20 trucks of aid, of course this number is not in any way sufficient to cover the humanitarian need in Gaza , since there is a humanitarian crisis in the strip, the deteriorating conditions in the strip requires a lot more than aid, initially what is needed, is the stop of the aggression on Gaza, and then the rebuilding of Gaza and elevating the humanitarian situation of the population," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military has updated the number of people believed to be held hostage in Gaza to 210. In a televised briefing, chief IDF spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the number does not include two American hostages who were returned to the Israeli military on Friday local time. According to news agency Reuters, a source briefed on the hostage negotiations called the release of the two Americans "a first step", adding that "discussions are ongoing for more releases". You can read more about that here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's military says 210 people are being held hostage in Gaza

featuredLink.title: Hereâs what we know about the mother and daughter released by Hamas, and what happens next

children.content: Israel's military has updated the number of people believed to be held hostage in Gaza to
In a televised briefing, chief IDF spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the number does not include two American hostages who were returned to the Israeli military on Friday local time.
According to news agency Reuters, a source briefed on the hostage negotiations called the release of the two Americans "a first step", adding that "discussions are ongoing for more releases".
You can read more about that here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's Cherine Yazbeck is in Lebanon covering the war. She spoke to freelance journalist Muthanna Al Najjar, who followed Hamas militants into Israel two weeks ago, despite not being involved in the group. Muthanna saw the breach in the fence separating Gaza from Israel and went through, eventually travelling to the Nir Oz kibbutz where Hamas committed atrocities. "I had never traveled this far. I was seeing the other side of the wall for the first time," he says. Muthanna, 39, took his camera into the kibbutz and documented the terrifying events. "I felt compelled to record everything I witnessed," he says. "Had I not recorded, no one would've believed my account of what transpired." His goal wasn't to sensationalise or stir animosity but to portray the unvarnished truth, allowing his lens to reveal the stark reality of war. Twenty people were killed in the kibbutz and another 80 were taken hostage. Nir Oz Kibbutz lies in the northwestern Negev desert, nestled between Magen and Nirim. At the time of the assault, it was home to about 400 people. Muthanna says he told gunmen not to shoot a mother and her children there, as the attack unfolded. In a chilling video previously uploaded to Instagram (which he has since removed), Muthanna videoed himself as militants zoomed past on motorcycles. "My commitment to storytelling persists, irrespective of my personal feelings and the horrific scenes around," he says. Since 2007, Gaza has been under a blockade, severely limiting Palestinians' mobility outside Gaza. Muthanna says the experience had been difficult personally. "I have loved ones, and their safety weighs on me daily. They're innocents," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The journalist from Gaza who filmed Hamas attack

children.content: The ABC's
Cherine Yazbeck
is in Lebanon covering the war.
She spoke to freelance journalist Muthanna Al Najjar, who followed Hamas militants into Israel two weeks ago, despite not being involved in the group.

props.alt: A man speaks to the camera, while another man runs past with a gun.

children.content: Muthanna Al Najjar documented Hamas's attack in Nir Oz.
(Supplied: Muthanna Al Najjar)
Muthanna saw the breach in the fence separating Gaza from Israel and went through, eventually travelling to the Nir Oz kibbutz where Hamas committed atrocities.
"I had never traveled this far. I was seeing the other side of the wall for the first time," he says.
Muthanna, 39, took his camera into the kibbutz and documented the terrifying events.
"I felt compelled to record everything I witnessed," he says.
"Had I not recorded, no one would've believed my account of what transpired."

props.alt: Two men holding guns, seen from behind.

children.content: Gunmen can be seen in Nir Oz.
(Supplied: Muthanna Al Najjar)
His goal wasn't to sensationalise or stir animosity but to portray the unvarnished truth, allowing his lens to reveal the stark reality of war.
Twenty people were killed in the kibbutz and another 80 were taken hostage.
Nir Oz Kibbutz lies in the northwestern Negev desert, nestled between Magen and Nirim. At the time of the assault, it was home to about 400 people.
Muthanna says he told gunmen not to shoot a mother and her children there, as the attack unfolded.

props.alt: A man speaking to a camera while a large crowd of people can be seen in the distance behind him

children.content: Muthanna Al Najjar is a freelance journalist from Gaza.
(Supplied: Muthanna Al Najjar)
In a chilling video previously uploaded to Instagram (which he has since removed), Muthanna videoed himself as militants zoomed past on motorcycles.
"My commitment to storytelling persists, irrespective of my personal feelings and the horrific scenes around," he says.
Since 2007, Gaza has been under a blockade, severely limiting Palestinians' mobility outside Gaza.
Muthanna says the experience had been difficult personally.
"I have loved ones, and their safety weighs on me daily. They're innocents," he says.

props.alt: Flames and smoke engulfing a building.

children.content: A large fire can be seen during the Hamas attack at Nir Oz.
(Supplied: Muthanna Al Najjar)
